Notes: Primary schools have now re-opened since 10 February 2012. Universities and secondary level school were already allowed to hold in-person classes. Only missing are preschools (children age 3-6) which are scheduled to open March 3rd.    Strong restrictions are in place for in-person classes, including social distancing, hand-washing, etc...     sources: http://archive.today/2021.02.16-144244/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://archive.today/2021.02.16-144845/https://jornalnorthnews.com/noticia/409/alunos-do-ensino-primario-voltam-as-aulas-na-angola  http://archive.today/2021.02.16-145224/https://governo.gov.ao/ao/noticias/medidas-a-vigorar-ate-11-de-marco/

Policy: Primary schools, secondary schools, and universities are permitted to hold in-person classes.?  Preschools are permitted to open as of March 15, 2021 for students aged 3 to 6.  Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307205259/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Overall, sectors are open with limited capacity and some hourly restrictions.    This summarises the situation quite well: Health centers and hospitals are fully operational.  Restaurants are open from 6a.m. to 9p.m. for table service, and from 6a.m. to 10p.m. for takeout.? In person dining is limited to 50 percent capacity with no more than four guests per table.? Stores, including supermarkets, can remain open until 10p.m.? Museums and monuments, movie theaters, cultural and art fairs, libraries, and media centers are open but limited to 50 percent capacity.? Religious activities are limited to four days a week with no more than 50 percent capacity or 150 people and are limited to a maximum duration of 2 hours if held in enclosed spaces.    sources: http://archive.today/2021.02.16-144244/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://archive.today/2021.02.16-145224/https://governo.gov.ao/ao/noticias/medidas-a-vigorar-ate-11-de-marco/
No update.  Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307205259/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Gatherings are limited, but exercising, sporting events and religious activities may occur with, respectively, at most 10 and 150 people.    sources: http://archive.today/2021.02.16-145224/https://governo.gov.ao/ao/noticias/medidas-a-vigorar-ate-11-de-marco/  http://archive.today/2021.02.16-144244/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

This is slightly confusing. I think currently quarantine is required together with COVID negative tests pre-arrival, on arrival and after quarantine. This definitely applies to countries with new COVID variants, e.g. Brazil, Portugal, South africa.    source: http://archive.today/2021.02.16-145224/https://governo.gov.ao/ao/noticias/medidas-a-vigorar-ate-11-de-marco/  http://archive.today/2021.02.16-144244/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Policy: There is a two pronged approach here. International travel from certain countries are banned. These countries are the following: South Africa, Australia, Nigeria, United Kingdom, Portugal, and Brazil. Otherwise, "limited international travel is permitted for only citizens or residents of the country, humanitarian transport, medical emergencies, and diplomatic missions. Persons entering the country require a negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before arrival. Travelers must also undergo a rapid COVID-19 test immediately on disembarking the plane. Travelers who test negative may continue; however, positive travelers will be quarantined at a government facility."  Source:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307205259/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307211436/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/435351/angola-authorities-amend-covid-19-measures-as-of-jan-27-update-17

Angola received it's first batch of vaccines from COVAX on the 4th of March and has already jabbed 90 plus people. It's stated priority groups are as follows: health professionals, teachers, defense and security forces, and people with comorbidities. I've coded all of these individuals as three groups: the healthcare force, the "essential" workforce meaning teachers, defense services, and thirdly, those with co-morbidities. Night clubs and karaoke bars in Burundi are closed until further notice.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210223004727/https://bi.usembassy.gov/alert-01132021/    large gatherings can be seen particularly with family, religious and cultural events. There was no national lock down and it has been businesses as normal in many areas of society.  For example, soccer matches have continued, as have large-scale group exercises, parties, weddings, and other activities.  Burundians have stopped hugging and shaking hands to some extent, and many public venues have handwashing stations installed. https://archive.vn/yxS66#selection-2661.309-2661.654

https://web.archive.org/web/20210207205721/https://bi.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  Melchior Ndadaye International airport reopened on November 8, 2020. The Ministry of Health expanded prevention measures related to COVID-19 for all travelers arriving to Burundi.  Measures are regularly updated and subject to change without notice.  All passengers arriving at Bujumbura’s Melchior Ndadaye’s international airport will be transported to designated hotels approved by the Government of Burundi.  Travelers must make hotel reservations at Government of Burundi approved quarantine hotel before arriving.   Upon arrival, travelers will be tested at the airport for COVID-19.   Burundi’s land and water borders remain closed. The county has registered more than 1,600 confirmed coronavirus cases. https://web.archive.org/web/20210209114515/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/tanzania-burundi-not-to-get-covid-19-vaccine-doses/2135487

All travelers must present a negative COVID-19 PCR (nasal swab) test upon arrival in Ouagadougou.  The test result must be dated within five days of arrival and can be in English or French.  If positive test quarantine for 14 days.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210201215615/https://bf.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

"All travelers arriving in Burkina Faso must present proof of having tested negative for COVID-19 using a test taken no more than five days before arrival. Travelers without such proof must submit to a test at the port of entry and face up to 14 days of quarantine at home or in a hotel of choice if positive. Authorities also perform temperature checks at airports. Travelers departing the country must also present negative results from COVID-19 test taken no more than five days before travel"    Source:  https://archive.is/kPkhZ

Land borders have been and remain closed. Only airports are open. This is a change from what has been reported previously, but land borders have been closed for an extended period of time. https://web.archive.org/web/20210228155615/https://bf.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

However - I did find that they do have support for business and lowering import duties and VAT for hygiene and healthcare goods and services critical to tackle COVID-19, and for tourism businesses; (ii) lowering other selected tax rates; (iii) delaying tax payments, and waiving late payment fines and penalties; (iv) suspending government fees charged on informal sector operators for rent, security and parking in urban markets; (v) lowering the licensing fee for companies in the transportation and tourism sectors; (vi) suspending on-site tax inspection operations; (vii) Donating food and providing assistance to households and local small businesses; (viii) supporting the water and electricity bills, including through cancelation, of the most vulnerable social groups; and (ix) securing adequate stocks of consumer products and strengthening surveillance of prices.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210207221300/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

There was a learning crisis in Botswana even before COVID-19 shuttered schools down. A third of grade 5 students in 2017 were unable to do basic subtraction and a fifth unable to read a simple paragraph.[i] This learning crisis will likely be worsened by school closures due to the COVID-19 pandemic.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208003633/https://www.orfonline.org/expert-speak/education-in-2021-perspectives-from-botswana/
Schools open since 12 January.     See school terms on government website (https://web.archive.org/web/20210222192106/https://www.gov.bw/school-terms).
Schools open since 12 January, health and safety recommendations in place.     See school terms on government website (https://web.archive.org/web/20210222192106/https://www.gov.bw/school-terms).

Stay home to protect yourself and others from COVID-19. Airports, bus stations, train stations, and rest stops are all places travelers can be exposed to the virus. These are also places where it can be hard to social distance. If you travel, take steps before, during, and after travel to keep yourself and others from getting COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208004744/https://www.mmegi.bw/

The majority of workplaces and businesses open with health and safety protocols in place.    State of Public Emergency in place from September until the end of March, see earlier gazetted guidelines (https://web.archive.org/web/20210222203002/https://www.caab.co.bw/wp-content/uploads/Government-Gazette-Extraordinary.pdf). See also UK government travel advice (https://web.archive.org/web/20210222192726/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/botswana/coronavirus).

Workplaces are open with COVID-19 healthy measure recommendations in place.    State of Public Emergency in place from September until the end of March, see earlier gazetted guidelines (https://web.archive.org/web/20210222203002/https://www.caab.co.bw/wp-content/uploads/Government-Gazette-Extraordinary.pdf).

The escalation of the dreaded coronavirus (COVID-19) cases in Botswana could see sports activities halted.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208010652/https://www.mmegi.bw/index.php?aid=88510&dir=2021%2Fjanuary%2F29

Informal public events prohibited, maximum 50 persons in meetings, societies, funerals, faith-based services etc.     State of Public Emergency in place from September until the end of March, see earlier gazetted guidelines (https://web.archive.org/web/20210222203002/https://www.caab.co.bw/wp-content/uploads/Government-Gazette-Extraordinary.pdf).

All informal public events of more than two people prohibited.     State of Public Emergency in place from September until the end of March, see earlier gazetted guidelines (https://web.archive.org/web/20210222203002/https://www.caab.co.bw/wp-content/uploads/Government-Gazette-Extraordinary.pdf). See also the adjustments made 26 February (https://archive.vn/qkysx).
No change to gatherings.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210208011052/https://allafrica.com/stories/202101220294.html

Maximum 50 persons in meetings, societies, funerals, faith-based services etc. with social distancing in place.    State of Public Emergency in place from September until the end of March, see earlier gazetted guidelines (https://web.archive.org/web/20210222203002/https://www.caab.co.bw/wp-content/uploads/Government-Gazette-Extraordinary.pdf).

All gatherings restricted until the end of March with exceptions for funerals, religious services, workshops.     State of Public Emergency in place from September until the end of March, see earlier gazetted guidelines (https://web.archive.org/web/20210222203002/https://www.caab.co.bw/wp-content/uploads/Government-Gazette-Extraordinary.pdf). See also the adjustments made 26 February (https://archive.vn/qkysx).

Is public transportation operating? Yes. Masks are required at all times on public transportation. Buses and vans operate at full capacity and do not always follow guidelines, so passengers should exercise extra caution when using public transportation.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210208011805/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No measures to close public transport.    State of Public Emergency in place from September until the end of March, see earlier gazetted guidelines (https://web.archive.org/web/20210222203002/https://www.caab.co.bw/wp-content/uploads/Government-Gazette-Extraordinary.pdf).

No measures to close public transport.    State of Public Emergency in place from September until the end of March, see earlier gazetted guidelines (https://web.archive.org/web/20210222203002/https://www.caab.co.bw/wp-content/uploads/Government-Gazette-Extraordinary.pdf).

Is a curfew in place? Yes. A curfew for Gaborone is in place through January 31, 2021 and bans all movement between 8pm and 4am.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208011805/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Nationwide curfew in place until 28 February from 8PM until 4AM.    State of Public Emergency in place from September until the end of March, see earlier gazetted guidelines (https://web.archive.org/web/20210222203002/https://www.caab.co.bw/wp-content/uploads/Government-Gazette-Extraordinary.pdf). See also UK government travel advice (https://web.archive.org/web/20210222192726/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/botswana/coronavirus).
Curfew from extended until the end of March, occurs from 10PM until 4AM.     See adjustments announced on 26 February (https://archive.vn/qkysx).

Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes. Botswana is divided into 9 geographical zones (map available at www.gov.bw) and permits are only needed to travel between zones.  Residents may travel within their zone without permits. Permits for inter-zone travel may be acquired online at www.gov.bw and are restricted to essential travel. COVID-19 tests may be required at any time for those transiting zones. Tourism is considered essential travel for economic reasons, and Botswana residents may organize permit applications with a reservation confirmation from their destination lodging.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208011805/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Permits needed for inter-zonal travel.    State of Public Emergency in place from September until the end of March, see earlier gazetted guidelines (https://web.archive.org/web/20210222203002/https://www.caab.co.bw/wp-content/uploads/Government-Gazette-Extraordinary.pdf).

Permits needed in order to travel between zones.    State of Public Emergency in place from September until the end of March, see earlier gazetted guidelines (https://web.archive.org/web/20210222203002/https://www.caab.co.bw/wp-content/uploads/Government-Gazette-Extraordinary.pdf).

Are U.S. citizens required to quarantine? No. All persons entering Botswana are required to have a negative PCR test within 72 hours of their departure for Botswana. If they do not meet this requirement upon entry, they will be tested at the Port of Entry. With a negative test, they are not required to quarantine.  Persons who are symptomatic upon entry or who develop COVID after entry must self-isolate for 10 days with a test in the second half of the isolation period. Close contacts of positive COVID patients will be asked to isolate for 14 days.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208011805/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

All travellers arriving should have a valid 72 hour PCR negative test.    State of Public Emergency in place from September until the end of March, see earlier gazetted guidelines (https://web.archive.org/web/20210222203002/https://www.caab.co.bw/wp-content/uploads/Government-Gazette-Extraordinary.pdf).

All travellers arriving should have a valid 72 hour PCR negative test. COVID-19 Testing:    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Botswana? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? No  Antigen (rapid) tests are available at the international airports and major land border crossings. PCR tests are available for U.S. citizens at two locations: Sir Ketumile Masire Teaching Hospital and Diagnofirm Medical Laboratories, both in Gaborone.  Teaching Hospital PCR tests are 500 BWP and results can be slower than 48-72 hours as this is the main testing facility for everyone in country and is cheaper than Diagnofirm. Diagnofirm offers PCR tests for 999 BWP which are available in less than 24 hours. Antigen test costs range from 150 to 500 BWP. All testing is paid for by the patient. The Teaching Hospital price of 500 BWP is a price limit set by the Government of Botswana and is therefore partially subsidized.  Test results are delivered by text message/SMS. Expect delays in messaging even if the results are complete on time.  Testing regulations and information change frequently. If you are in Botswana and experiencing symptoms, contact your physician and the Government of Botswana COVID hotline at 997 for instructions.  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions for travel to the United States, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208011805/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Public places and services  A national curfew is in place in response to outbreaks of violence, following presidential and legislative elections. This curfew comes into effect at 8pm and ends at 5am. You should follow the government’s instructions and avoid travel around Bangui during these hours.    The following measures remain in place:    it is compulsory to wear face masks in public places;  no handshakes or kissing, instead use non-contact greetings for social interactions;  public spaces must have hand-washing stations;  places of worship and restaurants remain open;  staying in your house or accommodation is encouraged.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210210124349/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/central-african-republic/coronavirus
none due to covid - civil unrest is causing the closures https://archive.vn/Atcsk

Transportation Options:    Are commercial flights operating? Yes, however airline schedules often change with little notice. Please monitor your flight status on a continual basis.  Is public transportation operating? Yes  Public transportation is considered dangerous and it is not recommended to travel by mini-bus or moto-taxis (motorcycles).  Private cabs are available.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213111451/https://cf.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
none due to covid - "Is public transportation operating? Yes" https://archive.vn/Atcsk

Minimal domestic restrictions remain in place following the easing of measures in recent months; social distancing measures, including the use of protective facemasks, is compulsory in all public spaces and public transportation, though this measure is not strictly enforced. Noncontact greetings for social interactions are reportedly being enforced in Bangui. A security-related state of emergency and 1800-0500 curfew are in place.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210218142228/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/444751/central-african-republic-nationwide-covid-19-restrictions-remain-largely-unchanged-as-of-feb-18-update-5

https://web.archive.org/web/20210215141307/https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/covid-4/coronavirus-central-african-republic    CDC advises people to take precautionary measures before, during and after travel.

Entry to CAR  Some incoming passengers need to undertake a (COVID-19) test on arrival. You should arrange to take a private test.    Some air companies and airports also require a negative COVID-19 test prior to boarding to CAR. You should check with your travel provider.    Do not use the NHS testing service to get a test in order to facilitate your travel to another country.    Some of CAR neighbouring countries have started to re-open their land borders, including those with CAR This includes Democratic Republic of Congo and Sudan.    Screening on arrival  All travellers entering CAR are required to wear face masks, use hand sanitiser, have their body temperatures taken and disinfect luggage among other measures.    Quarantine requirements  14 days self-isolation is mandatory for any person entering CAR who is coming from a location with local transmission of COVID-19.    Airline companies must also cooperate with the government of CAR concerning quarantine and other measures necessary to manage the spread of coronavirus.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210222164636/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/central-african-republic/entry-requirements

U.S. citizens are required to quarantine for 14 days.  However, if you are a member of an international organization or humanitarian NGO, a quarantine is only required until you receive a negative COVID-19 test at the local Pasteur Institute.  The cost of the test is approximately US$70.00 (CFA35,000)     https://archive.vn/Atcsk

COVID-19 Testing    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in the Central African Republic? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  For symptomatic patients, testing is free and available at the Ministry of Health and Institute Pasteur.  For pre-departure testing, travelers should go to the Pasteur Institute in Bangui.  Their current hours are 7:00am to 11:15am Monday to Saturday and testing is first come, first serve.  Tests are approximately $75 and should be paid in local currency.   Tests are generally available within 48 hours via email.  https://reports.unocha.org/en/country/car/card/7jsVXwSZcV/  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions to CDC’s requirement that all U.S. bound travelers present a negative COVID test, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html  Humanitarian exemptions to this order will be granted on an extremely limited basis and will only be considered when the country of departure lacks adequate COVID-19 testing capacity.  To submit information in support of an exemption, e-mail YaoundeACS@state.gov.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213111451/https://cf.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

For symptomatic patients, testing is free and available at the Ministry of Health and Institute Pasteur.  For pre-departure testing, travelers should go to the Pasteur Institute in Bangui.  Their current hours are 7:00am to 11:15am Monday to Saturday and testing is first come, first serve.  Tests are approximately $75 and should be paid in local currency. Tests are generally available within 48 hours via email. https://archive.vn/Atcsk

According to the US Embassy in Cameroon, the Cameroonian government has updated the previous policy of mandatory quarantine for travelers. Air passengers with a positive COVID-19 test result will be required to enter isolation at home or in a government facility at their own expense depending on their symptoms. Although quarantine is not required, travelers may have been exposed to COVID-19 during their travels and are encouraged to limit contact with others for 14 days after their trip. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210221154149/https://cm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

According to the US Embassy, the border is officially closed but certain airlines have been given authorization to operate flights from Douala and Yaounde. Upon arrival, there are screening protocols at the airport. A negative test three days prior to arrival is required. The land and sea borders remain closed to humans. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210301033018/https://cm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

According to the US Embassy in Cameroon, there are screenings and one is required to have a negative test taken in the last 72 hours. There are limited flights in operation. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210308050348/https://cm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No new information was gathered but in the second quarter of 2020, there was exemption from the withholding tax for taxis and motorbikes and petty traders.   Other measures aim to alleviate the impact on households, in particular (i) an increase in the family allowance from CFAF 2,800 to CFAF 4,500; (ii) a raise of 20 percent for pensions that did not benefit from the 2016 reform; (iii) continued payment of family allowances from May to July to staff of companies which are unable to pay social security contributions or which have placed their staff on technical leave due to the crisis.    Please see: https://archive.vn/VQK2X

According to the COVID -19 Stimulus tracker, the household allowance was increased from 2800 CFA to 4500 CFA in May of 2020. Please see: https://archive.vn/aRFaa  Here is a link to a reporting page on the change in policy. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210221154731/https://www.businessincameroon.com/social/1305-10317-cnps-other-social-benefits-will-rise-with-the-family-allowance

According to the US Embassy in Cameroon, The following facilities provide COVID-19 testing in Cameroon: Centre Pasteur and National Public Health Laboratory in Yaounde, and the Laquintinie Hospital in Douala. The Cameroon government has announced that these tests are free of charge.  Once the patient submits their sample, results are sent to him/her by email, text message, or physical copy within 24 hours unless otherwise specified by the testing facility.    Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210214213709/https://cm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Once the patient submits their sample, results are sent to him/her by email, text message, or physical copy within 24 hours unless otherwise specified by the testing facility. Travellers moving from one province to another must present a negative coronavirus test result. The test result date must fall within 3 days before the date you intend to leave the province.   /web/20210215163126/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/coronavirus
there's a curfew. https://archive.vn/QaXY6  there are no intercity or interstate restrictions https://archive.vn/RNjFp

All travellers entering DRC are subject to screening, including temperature checks.    Travellers aged 11 and above need to provide proof of a negative coronavirus test upon entry to DRC. The test result date must be within the 7 days prior to your arrival date. Children under the age of 11 are exempt.    Travellers aged 11 and above must also pay $45 USD for a mandatory test on arrival    You must provide proof of a negative test for coronavirus upon departure. The test result date must fall within 3 days before your departure date and be provided by either INRB (Institut National de Recherche Biomédicale – The National Institute of Biomedical Research) or a medical facility approved by them.    You may be subjecting to screening, including temperature checks, when leaving DRC.  /web/20210215164738/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/entry-requirements

Domestic travelers age 11 and older are required to present a negative COVID-19 test for travel between the provinces when departing from Kinshasa, Lubumbashi, Bukavu, Goma, and Kisangani. Where possible, the test must be taken within 7 days of travel. https://archive.vn/RNjFp

There is a nationwide curfew in the DRC each evening from 9 pm to 5 am. Masks are required in public spaces.  Businesses, schools, airports, and ports are open.  While DRC permits borders open, many neighboring countries continue to restrict border crossings:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210225010659/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Public places and services  A curfew is in place from 18 December between 9pm and 5am. You should not be outside without justifiable reason (eg a medical emergency during these hours).    Wearing of facemasks is mandatory for anyone in public areas. This includes in public and private transport. The police will issue fines of 5000 Congolese Francs ($3) if masks are not worn.    DRC authorities have announced the following public health measures:    businesses, banks, restaurants and shops have re-opened in Kinshasa with social distancing measures in place.  places of worship, stadiums and performance halls have reopened with social distancing measures in place.  schools, colleges and universities are closed.  social enterprises eg bars and nightclubs remain closed  Public health measures can change at short notice and you should monitor local media for the latest developments.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308153330/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/coronavirus

According to the Congolese government, more than 50 people cannot gather. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210207044617/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-21-janvier-2021/

The fllowing restrictions are in place;  1. More than 50 people cannot gather.   2. To lift bodies from the morgue, only 10 family members are allowed to be present.   3. The opening of state markets in Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire is limited to five days (Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday).   4. Group walks of more than three people on public roads and spaces, in particular the corniche and the surroundings of the Brazzaville stadiums as well as the shores of the Atlantic Ocean in Pointe-Noire and in the Kouilou are prohibited.  5. The installation on the track and public spaces of marquees intended to accommodate people is prohibited.  Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210214134108/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-11-fevrier-2021/

The Congolese authorities still have the curfew in Pointe Noire and Brazzaville. The curfew in Brazzaville and Pointe Noire is from 23:00 until 05:00, Mondays through Fridays and from 20:00 until 05:00 on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.  Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210207044617/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-21-janvier-2021/

The government maintains the curfew in Pointe Noire and Brazzaville from 11 p.m. to 5 a.m. on working days, and from 8 p.m. to 5 a.m. on Saturdays and Sundays as well as on public holidays. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210214134108/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-11-fevrier-2021/

As the government extended the state of emergency, the curfew in place are still on. The curfew in Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire, from 11 p.m. to 5 a.m. on working days, and from 8 p.m. to 5 a.m. on Saturdays and Sundays as well as on public holidays. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210221125448/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-11-fevrier-2021/

The following measures are in place and may be amended at short notice:  a curfew remains in place in Pointe-Noire and Brazzaville from 11pm until 5am  face masks must be worn in all public places:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210225010659/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Public places and services  A curfew is in place from 18 December between 9pm and 5am. You should not be outside without justifiable reason (eg a medical emergency during these hours).    Wearing of facemasks is mandatory for anyone in public areas. This includes in public and private transport. The police will issue fines of 5000 Congolese Francs ($3) if masks are not worn.    DRC authorities have announced the following public health measures:    businesses, banks, restaurants and shops have re-opened in Kinshasa with social distancing measures in place.  places of worship, stadiums and performance halls have reopened with social distancing measures in place.  schools, colleges and universities are closed.  social enterprises eg bars and nightclubs remain closed  Public health measures can change at short notice and you should monitor local media for the latest developments.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308153330/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/coronavirus    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308160828/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
So far, there are no known internal restrictions according to the US Embassy in Congo. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210207045006/https://cg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

There are no internal movement restrictions but the government plans to continue the exercise of health checks and those of the public force at the entry and exit of all towns in the country. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210214134108/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-11-fevrier-2021/

There are no restrictions to movement but there are health checks at the entry and exit of all towns in the country. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210221125448/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-11-fevrier-2021/
No restriction on internal movement:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210225010659/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Movement Restrictions:    Is a curfew in place? Yes  A nationwide curfew is in place each evening from 9 pm to 5 am.  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  Domestic travelers age 11 and older are required to present a negative COVID-19 test for travel between the provinces when departing from Kinshasa, Lubumbashi, Bukavu, Goma, and Kisangani. Where possible, the test must be taken within 7 days of travel.  Check with your airline about COVID-19 safety measures, testing requirements, and health requirements at your destination.     Source:
According to the US Embassy, the quarantine measures are still in place for foreigners. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210207045006/https://cg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

In addition to the quarantine measures, the government requires the presentation, at the border, of a negative PCR test of less than 72 hours for all passengers arriving in Congo, with the exception of children under ten (10) years old. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210214134108/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-11-fevrier-2021/    Also see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210214140802/https://cg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

According to the US Embassy in Congo, all international passengers are required to self-quarantine for two weeks in their residence or hotel for 14 day upon arrival. Passengers in transit will be quarantined at their expense at designated facilities until they resume their travels. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210221135248/https://cg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

According to the US Embassy in Congo, all international passengers are required to self-quarantine for two weeks in their residence or hotel for 14 day upon arrival. Passengers in transit will be quarantined at their expense at designated facilities until they resume their travels:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210225010659/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Entry and Exit Requirements:    Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? Yes  Is a negative COVID-19 test required for entry? Yes  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? Yes  Is a negative COVID-19 test required for departure? Yes  DRC Requirements:  All arriving international travelers age 11 and older must arrive with proof of a negative COVID-19 test from within 3 days of their departure to DRC. Upon arrival, travelers age 11 and older must also submit to a COVID-19 test at the airport.  Travelers should register their information and pay for the test at INRBCOVID.com before they start their travel.  The cost of the required test is US$45 which can be paid in U.S. cash at the airport.  Following the sample collection at the airport, passengers must self-quarantine until they receive a negative test result via the website and/or SMS, generally within 24 hours.  All travelers must present a World Health Organization (WHO) card with proof of yellow fever vaccination.  U.S. citizens should travel with proof of health and medical evacuation insurance. Check with your medical evacuation insurance company on options should you fall ill in the DRC.  To exit the DRC, all passengers age 11 and older must present a negative COVID-19 test from the INRB or a laboratory approved by the Ministry of Health, from within 3 days prior to departure. The cost of the test through the INRB is US$30.  Visit INRBCOVID.com for information on testing in the DRC.     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308152633/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/entry-requirements

The world bank made provision for about $20 million and the state added 3 billion CFA which is equivalent to $5,542,680 according to exchange rate.org. (the rate as at 12th of February,2021 is 1 CFA to 0.001848 USD) will be made available for the 339,143 eligible households. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210214134108/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-11-fevrier-2021/

The government mentioned the plan to provide economic support to members of the vulnerable population. A grant of a flat-rate allowance of 200,000 households, at the rate of 50,000 CFA francs per household. The additional resources granted by the World Bank (US $ 20 million) and State funding of around 3 billion CFA francs should be sufficient to pay the planned allocation to 339,143 eligible households. Please see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210221125448/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-11-fevrier-2021/

While DRC permits borders open, many neighboring countries continue to restrict border crossings:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210225010659/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Public places and services  A curfew is in place from 18 December between 9pm and 5am. You should not be outside without justifiable reason (eg a medical emergency during these hours).    Wearing of facemasks is mandatory for anyone in public areas. This includes in public and private transport. The police will issue fines of 5000 Congolese Francs ($3) if masks are not worn.    DRC authorities have announced the following public health measures:    businesses, banks, restaurants and shops have re-opened in Kinshasa with social distancing measures in place.  places of worship, stadiums and performance halls have reopened with social distancing measures in place.  schools, colleges and universities are closed.  social enterprises eg bars and nightclubs remain closed  Public health measures can change at short notice and you should monitor local media for the latest developments.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308153330/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/coronavirus

There are plans in the works for this;  Clément MOUAMBA, Prime Minister, Head of Government, informed the members of the National Coordination that, in accordance with the guidelines previously given by His Excellency, Mr. Denis SASSOU N'GUESSO, President of the Republic, Head of State, a Committee Ad Hoc on vaccines was put in place; this Committee, made up of ten members and made up of a large panel of specialists in the various aspects inherent in this question, is responsible for diligently carrying out a broad reflection, so that our country chooses as soon as possible the vaccine (s) suitable for our situation.  Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210214134108/https://gouvernement.cg/coronavirus-communique-de-la-coordination-nationale-de-gestion-de-la-pandemie-de-coronavirus-covid-19-suite-a-sa-reunion-du-jeudi-11-fevrier-2021/

No vaccination available currently, The Republic of Congo will receive a donation of 100,000 doses of Covid-19 vaccines from China to help the country inoculate its population against the virus:  https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-02-05/congo-republic-to-get-100-0000-doses-of-covid-vaccine-from-china
Some vaccines have arrived in Congo, but citizens haven't started receiving them yet.

In a "clarification" to the guidelines issued on December 21. the Eritrean High Level Task Force on Covid-19 is reported by the US Embassy in Eritrea to have announced that "Except those who work in activities related to development, safety, and essential services, everyone must avoid unnecessary movement and remain at home. Except for emergency cases or food purchases, all movement done – whether by foot, bicycle, cart, or car – is prohibited." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210104214528/https://er.usembassy.gov/december-26-announcement-from-the-eritrean-government-on-clarification-of-covid-19-guidelines/
This is a conservative logical deduction given general restrictions on internal movement and closure of businesses etc.

No change, "Public Transportation has stopped services until further notice and private cars are banned from the road without a permit." - https://web.archive.org/web/20210208221936/https://er.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Guidelines from the High Level Task Force on COVID-19 https://web.archive.org/web/20210215025725/https://shabait.com/2020/12/21/guidelines-from-the-high-level-task-force-on-covid-19-5/ state that:    1.    Movement of all citizens will be restricted except in cases of indispensable developmental, service and security tasks that are authorized by the respective competent bodies.  2.    Travel from one village/city to another village/city in the country will be banned.  3.    With the exception of those given specific permits, the use of private cars and other individual means of transport will not be allowed in this period.  Trucks are exempted from this restriction for tasks limited to freight services only.

Policy: Under the guidelines, all citizens' movement is restricted except for essential personnel, such as security workers or those with special authorization. Travel from one village or city to another in the country is banned. Internal travel requires approval from authorities. Private vehicles and other individual means of transportation are not allowed to operate.     These policies are being enforced by local authorities and watch groups.   Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210222090104/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/443016/eritrea-health-officials-maintain-covid-19-restrictions-nationwide-as-of-feb-15-update-7

No policy change found. Land borders remain closed, commercial flights are not available, though entry is possible via Government-approved charter flight - https://web.archive.org/web/20210208221936/https://er.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Land borders remain officially closed. Charter airline flights are occasionally available - https://web.archive.org/web/20210208221936/https://er.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Legal residents are able to apply for permission to return to Eritrea as of September 14 2020, and will need to spend 14 days in quarantine upon return. https://web.archive.org/web/20201115163552/https://us.embassyeritrea.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Er_Legal_Residents_Returnees_COVID-19.pdf

Policy:   All borders remain closed; chartered and humanitarian flights require government approval and permitted arriving travelers must quarantine for 14 days. Cargo and freight will likely face heightened screening measures. The Eritrean Ministry of Information reported that "public service messages and information about COVID-19 were developed and translated into all nine local languages (as well as sign language) and have been regularly disseminated through various forms of media (national television and radio). Safety, prevention, and hygiene guidelines have also been delivered through short message services for cellular telephones, and three “24/7” toll-free hotlines were established to provide information on health, hygiene, and prevention, and to report symptoms. Additionally, informational posters and pamphlets have been put on display in pharmacies, health clinics, shopping areas, on billboards and notice boards, and within other public spaces. Safety messages and themes were also integrated into popular television and radio programs, while popular artists recorded songs and videos supporting the national campaign against COVID-19." published November 2, 2020. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201112190842/https://shabait.com/2020/10/31/covid-19-eritreas-success-and-challenges-part-i/    No updates have been found since this time.

Schools in Gabon currently open.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210131150420/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/gabon/coronavirus

Public places and services  Markets have reopened as normal.    Restaurants with a terrace have reopened. A valid negative COVID-19 tests is compulsory for access to a restaurant. Cost of tests are 5000 CFA or approximately £7.00.    Gatherings of more than 30 people are banned, however, parliament and educational institutions are exempt from this limit.    All place of worship can only open one day a week. Places of worship with a maximum of 30 people have to observe the ‘sanitary protocol’ which includes compulsory wearing of masks, hand sanitisation, and social distancing.    Schools have reopened.    Bars, beaches and places of worship remain closed.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210215162704/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/gabon/coronavirus

Schools have reopened.    Bars, beaches and places of worship remain closed.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210222050709/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/gabon/coronavirus

Public places and services  Markets have reopened as normal.    Restaurants with a terrace have reopened. A valid negative COVID-19 tests is compulsory for access to a restaurant. Cost of tests are 5000 CFA or approximately £7.00.    Gatherings of more than 30 people are banned, however, parliament and educational institutions are exempt from this limit.    All place of worship can only open one day a week. Places of worship with a maximum of 30 people have to observe the ‘sanitary protocol’ which includes compulsory wearing of masks, hand sanitisation, and social distancing.    Schools will close at 3pm each day to comply with general curfew. Hospital visits are forbidden without authorisation from medical authorities.    Bars, beaches remain closed.    Access to restaurants and places of worship is subject to presentation of negative PCR test.    Wearing of masks in public is compulsory from the age of 5 years old.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210301115019/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/gabon/coronavirus

Event  Authorities in Gabon have tightened the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) measures as of Feb. 13. Officials have expanded an existing nighttime curfew; the measure will be in effect 1800-0500 daily. Authorities are also restricting entry and exit to Greater Libreville; individuals undertaking such travel require special authorization as well as proof of a negative COVID-19 test.    Officials have also indicated that several restrictions, including those related to the curfew, gatherings, social distancing, and the wearing of facemasks, will be more strictly enforced. Security checks will be established and enhanced, and monetary fines will be issued for non-compliance. A state of health emergency is also in place.    Domestic measures    A nationwide curfew 1800-0500.    Social gatherings are limited to 30 people.    Facemasks are mandatory in public areas and on public transportation.    There are capacity limits on public transport. Taxis may carry only three passengers.    Bars and nightclubs are closed.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210213123833/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/442486/gabon-officials-adjust-the-covid-19-related-curfew-to-1800-0500-from-feb-13-update-14

Gabon-Specific Information    The prevalence of COVID-19 cases in Gabon has recently increased, and government restrictions have tightened. As of January 25, the government has extended the curfew hours to 20:00 to 05:00.  Beginning the evening of January 30, land borders were closed except for government-approved crossings.  The government is monitoring the situation closely and has warned it will impose strong restrictions again should the situation worsen appreciably.  Churches and indoor dining are currently open at a maximum occupancy of 30 people. Fines for exceeding the 30-person limit on gatherings will range from 100,000 to 5,000,000 FCFA.  The wearing of facemasks is obligatory in all public spaces, to include riding or driving in a vehicle with two or more persons inside. If driving alone, the driver is required to have a facemask to be used immediately upon exiting the vehicle.  Fines for not wearing a facemask will range from 25,000 to 200,000 FCFA.  Social distancing and other hygiene requirements continue.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308031805/https://ga.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/coronavirus-update/

Domestic measures    A nationwide curfew 2000-0500.    Social gatherings are limited to 30 people.    Facemasks are mandatory in public areas and on public transportation.    Travel in and out of Libreville is permitted so long as a negative COVID-19 test was taken no longer than 14 days before entry or departure is provided. It is not clear if the same regulations apply for travel elsewhere in the country.    There are capacity limits on public transport. Taxis may carry only three passengers.    Bars and nightclubs are closed.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210125115708/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/433791/gabon-officials-adjust-the-covid-19-related-curfew-to-2000-0500-from-jan-25-update-13

Transportation Options    Are commercial flights operating?   Commercial air travel continues with three international flights per airline per week.  Crossing land and sea borders for commercial goods and services requires prior authorization.  Tourists are not permitted to arrive by land or sea.  Is public transportation operating? Yes  Masks are obligatory in all public transit vehicles. Taxis are operating at half capacity, limiting ridership to no more than 2 passengers per car.  Taxi buses are similarly limited in ridership.  In practice, however, many of these rules are ignored.

Entry to Gabon  Flight restrictions have eased to allow three flights per airline, per week. Land and sea borders are closed.    UK nationals must receive authorisation from the Gabonese Ministry of Foreign Affairs before travelling to Gabon. Authorisation can be obtained by sending an e-mail addressed to the ‘Minister’ or ‘Secretary General’ at the following e-mail address: ginetedzang2@gmail.com.    On arrival, all passengers must take a compulsory test for COVID-19 at Libreville Airport. Passengers are then required to self-isolate for 48 hours whilst the COVID-19 test is being processed. If the COVID-19 test is negative, passengers will be issued a test certificate, which is valid for 14 days and can be renewed at the end of this period after another test is undertaken.    If a COVID-19 test taken at the airport is positive, then passengers are required to continue self-isolation and await specific instructions from Gabonese health authorities. All COVID-19 tests taken in Gabon supersede any that were taken before arrival in Gabon.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210131145603/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/gabon/entry-requirements

Entry rules in response to coronavirus (COVID-19)  Entry to Gabon  Flight restrictions have eased to allow three flights per airline, per week. Land and sea borders are closed.    UK nationals must receive authorisation from the Gabonese Ministry of Foreign Affairs before travelling to Gabon. Authorisation can be obtained by sending an e-mail addressed to the ‘Minister’ or ‘Secretary General’ at the following e-mail address: ginetedzang2@gmail.com.    All passengers travelling to Gabon must present a valid negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test no older than 3 days for entry into Gabon.    On arrival, all passengers must take a compulsory test for COVID-19 at Libreville Airport. Passengers are then required to self-isolate for 48 hours whilst the COVID-19 test is being processed. If the COVID-19 test is negative, passengers will be issued a test certificate, which is valid for 14 days and can be renewed at the end of this period after another test is undertaken.    If a COVID-19 test taken at the airport is positive, then passengers are required to continue self-isolation and await specific instructions from Gabonese health authorities. All COVID-19 tests taken in Gabon supersede any that were taken before arrival in Gabon.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210301114536/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/gabon/entry-requirements

UK nationals must receive authorisation from the Gabonese Ministry of Foreign Affairs before travelling to Gabon. Authorisation can be obtained by sending an e-mail addressed to the ‘Minister’ or ‘Secretary General’ at the following e-mail address: ginetedzang2@gmail.com.    All passengers travelling to Gabon must present a valid negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test no older than 3 days for entry into Gabon.    On arrival, all passengers must take a compulsory test for COVID-19 at Libreville Airport. Passengers are then required to self-isolate for 48 hours whilst the COVID-19 test is being processed. If the COVID-19 test is negative, passengers will be issued a test certificate, which is valid for 14 days and can be renewed at the end of this period after another test is undertaken.    If a COVID-19 test taken at the airport is positive, then passengers are required to continue self-isolation and await specific instructions from Gabonese health authorities. All COVID-19 tests taken in Gabon supersede any that were taken before arrival in Gabon. FISCAL  The Amended Budget Law approved in end-June 2020 proposes the control of non-priority expenditure and redirects savings and development partners support of FCFA 73.9 billion (USD 138.1 million or 0.83 percent of GDP) to COVID-19 related spending. The government also plans to allocate additional FCFA 108 billion (USD 194.1 million or 1.2 percent of GDP) as an economic response, including through food stamps, electricity and water subsidies, direct support to SMEs and tax holidays. The Minister of Finance has created a fund available at their Caisse de Depots et Consignation (CDC) and designated a public accountant in order to facilitate disbursements of the health-related spending of that fund. An additional mechanism of around USD 375 million has further been announced to facilitate access to commercial banks financing for private (formal and informal) companies, including SMEs.    MONETARY AND MACRO-FINANCIAL  On March 27, 2020, BEAC announced a set of monetary easing measures including a decrease of the policy rate by 25 bps to 3.25 percent, a decrease of the Marginal Lending Facility rate by 100 bps to 5 percent, a suspension of absorption operations, an increase of liquidity provision from FCFA 240 to 500 billion, and a widening of the range of private instruments accepted as collateral in monetary operations. The MPC also supported BEAC’s management’s intent to propose to reduce haircuts applicable to private instruments accepted as collateral for refinancing operations, and to postpone by one-year principal repayment of consolidated central bank’s credits to member states, but these possible additional measures are not effective yet. Further, at its July 22, 2020, extraordinary Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) meeting the BEAC announced a new program of government securities purchases for the next 6 months. The purchase program is meant as a safety net, to ensure full cover of government securities issuances during the second half of 2020, while being consistent with BEAC Charter which prohibits direct monetary financing. The program will be based on revised securities issuance plans for each country, consistent with the latest revised budget laws and the budget financing frameworks agreed under the IMF programs. The BEAC also decided to resume liquidity injections with longer maturity, of up to one year.    On March 25, 2020, the COBAC informed banks that they can use their capital conservation buffers of 2.5 percent to absorb pandemic-related losses but requested banks to adopt a restrictive policy with regard to dividend distribution.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210301121744/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
No income support.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308034205/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Key Policy Responses as of March 4, 2021    FISCAL  The Amended Budget Law approved in end-June 2020 proposed the control of non-priority expenditure and redirects savings and development partners support of FCFA 73.9 billion (USD 138.1 million or 0.83 percent of GDP) to COVID-19 related spending. The government also plans to allocate additional FCFA 108 billion (USD 194.1 million or 1.2 percent of GDP) as an economic response, including through food stamps, electricity and water subsidies, direct support to SMEs and tax holidays. The Minister of Finance has created a fund available at their Caisse de Depots et Consignation (CDC) and designated a public accountant in order to facilitate disbursements of the health-related spending of that fund. An additional mechanism of around USD 375 million has further been announced to facilitate access to commercial banks financing for private (formal and informal) companies, including SMEs. The promulgated 2021 Budget Law allocates FCFA 3 billion (USD 6 million) for additional Covid-19 expenditures.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308034205/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Reopening of the economy. Since April 27, some of these measures were relaxed, including the full lockdown in Libreville. A second reopening wave started on July 1 with the reopening of commercial flights twice per week per company from Libreville and a reduced night curfew from 8pm till 5am. Since mid-August commercial flights were further relaxed to three flights per company per week departing from Gabon. Public schools reopened on November 7, 2020. Public gatherings are still not approved. Travelers departing to the countryside from the two main cities (Libreville and Franceville) must show a negative Covid-19 test performed up to five days prior to departure. Since early September, the test for domestic trips can be performed up to 14 days prior to departure. Travelers flying abroad must take the test if the destination country requires it, whereas all passengers arriving in Libreville’s airport must show a negative test performed in the last five days. At arrival, they are once more tested by Gabonese authorities in the airport for posterior tracing. On October 10, a new round of relaxation of the preventive measures have been announced, allowing restaurants and religious centers to resume activity and shortening the night curfew from 10pm till 5am. Such gradual reopening of the economy has been based on a comprehensive-testing strategy with a capability of around 10,000 tests to be performed per day and with the equivalent of more than twenty percent of the population tested, making the country one with the highest rates of testing per capita of sub-Saharan Africa. The Gabonese parliament has also launched at the end of the first semester a Parliamentary Inquire Committee to investigate the quality and transparency of the Covid-19 expenditures by the government. The Ministry of Health is currently preparing a national vaccination strategy against the disease. At the same time a second wave of infections has hit the country and some of the preventive measures have been strengthened, such as the return to the extended night curfew from 8pm till 6am.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210208113328/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  http://web.archive.org/web/20210131150420/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/gabon/coronavirus

COVID-19 Testing    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in GABON? Yes, PCR tests are available.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html.  COVID-19 PCR tests are 5,000 FCFA for in-country travel and 20,000 FCFA for international travel; these costs are covered by the individual requesting the testing.  A PCR test must be taken upon arrival in Gabon; the cost is now 20,000 FCFA per test.  The following sites offer COVID-19 testing in the greater Libreville area (https://infocovid.ga):  Hôpital de Campagne (Field Hospitals): Stade d’angondje  Centre de Santé (Health Centers): Awendje, Okala, Louis, Owendo, London, La Peyrie, Lalala, Nzeng Ayong, Glass  Centre Médicaux (Medical Centers): Ntoum  Hôpitaux (Hospitals): Hôpital de Nkembo, Hôpital Sino-gabonais, Hôpital égypto-gabonais  Centres Hospitaliers Régionaux (Regional Hospital Centers): MELEN  Centres Hospitaliers Universitaires (University Hospital Centers): Libreville, Owendo, Mère-Enfant Jeanne Ebori  Structures Privées (Private Institutions): Polyclinique Chambrier, Cabinet médical inter-entreprises, Cabinet ORL Dr Edzang  Unités Mobiles (Mobile Units): Gigi, aéroport, Charbonnages, Awendje, SNI  Hôpitaux Militaires (Military Hospitals): Akanda  Infirmeries Garde Républicaine (Republican Guard Clinics): Infirmerie principale, Groupement d’intervention parachutiste, Groupement aérien présidentiel  Infirmeries Gendarmerie Nationale (National Gendarmerie Clinics): Santé maternelle et infantile, Gros bouquet, Owendo  Infirmeries Forces De Police Nationale (National Police Force Clinics): Komo, Sorbonne, Santé maternelle et infantile Fopi  Infirmeries Forces Armées Gabonaises (Gabonese Armed Forces Clinics): Infirmerie principale Louembet (Baraka), 1er Régiment de parachutistes gabonais  Laboratoires (Laboratories): Laboratoire Professeur Daniel Gahouma, Laboratoire national de santé publique  COVID-19 test results are delivered to the patient by printed copy.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210207231917/https://ga.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/coronavirus-update/

Reopening of the economy. Since April 27, some of these measures were relaxed, including the full lockdown in Libreville. A second reopening wave started on July 1 with the reopening of commercial flights twice per week per company from Libreville and a reduced night curfew from 8pm till 5am. Since mid-August commercial flights were further relaxed to three flights per company per week departing from Gabon. Public schools reopened on November 7, 2020. Since early September, the test for domestic trips could be performed up to 14 days prior to departure. All passengers arriving in Libreville’s airport from abroad must show a negative test performed in the last five days. At arrival, they are once more tested by Gabonese authorities in the airport for posterior tracing. On October 10, a new round of relaxation of the preventive measures was announced, allowing restaurants and religious centers to resume activity and shortening the night curfew from 10pm till 5am. Such gradual reopening of the economy was based on a comprehensive-testing strategy with a capability of around 10,000 tests to be performed per day and with the equivalent of more than twenty-five percent of the population tested, making the country one with the highest rates of testing per capita of sub-Saharan Africa. The Gabonese parliament has also launched at the end of the first semester a Parliamentary Inquire Committee to investigate the quality and transparency of the Covid-19 expenditures by the government. The Ministry of Health is currently preparing a national vaccination strategy against the disease. At the same time an aggressive second wave of infections has hit the country and the preventive measures have been strengthened. The night curfew has been re-enlarged from 6 pm until 5am, causing business to close around 3pm. The capital, Libreville, has been put in confinement for domestic travelers and only two international flights per company can land in Gabon per week again. Masks became compulsory for the population above 5 years-old and restaurants and shops must demand a negative test from clients within the last seven days.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308034205/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Gabon is one of the countries in Africa conducting the highest number of tests.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210208113328/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Domestic measures    A nationwide curfew 2000-0500.    Social gatherings are limited to 30 people.    Facemasks are mandatory in public areas and on public transportation.    Travel in and out of Libreville is permitted so long as a negative COVID-19 test was taken no longer than 14 days before entry or departure is provided. It is not clear if the same regulations apply for travel elsewhere in the country.    There are capacity limits on public transport. Taxis may carry only three passengers.    Bars and nightclubs are closed.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210125115708/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/433791/gabon-officials-adjust-the-covid-19-related-curfew-to-2000-0500-from-jan-25-update-13  http://web.archive.org/web/20210131144656/https://ga.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/coronavirus-update/

The wearing of facemasks is obligatory in all public spaces, to include riding or driving in a vehicle with two or more persons inside. If driving alone, the driver is required to have a facemask to be used immediately upon exiting the vehicle.  Fines for not wearing a facemask will range from 25,000 to 200,000 FCFA.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210215160241/https://ga.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/coronavirus-update/

Gabon-Specific Information    The prevalence of COVID-19 cases in Gabon has recently increased, and government restrictions have tightened. As of January 25, the government has extended the curfew hours to 20:00 to 05:00.  Beginning the evening of January 30, land borders were closed except for government-approved crossings.  The government is monitoring the situation closely and has warned it will impose strong restrictions again should the situation worsen appreciably.  Churches and indoor dining are currently open at a maximum occupancy of 30 people. Fines for exceeding the 30-person limit on gatherings will range from 100,000 to 5,000,000 FCFA.  The wearing of facemasks is obligatory in all public spaces, to include riding or driving in a vehicle with two or more persons inside. If driving alone, the driver is required to have a facemask to be used immediately upon exiting the vehicle.  Fines for not wearing a facemask will range from 25,000 to 200,000 FCFA.  Social distancing and other hygiene requirements continue.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210301104458/https://ga.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/coronavirus-update/

"The Ghana Health Service lists open and closed sectors. Essential businesses continue to be open with enhanced hygiene measures but religious events, nightclubs and bars are closed, these policies apply nationwide. On January 31, 2021 the President gave his 23rd official update outlining the re-introduction of preventive measures. In relation to workplaces: ""All workplaces, public and private, must employ a shift-system for workers, in addition to the use of virtual platforms for business or work. Conferences and workshops can take place with all the appropriate protocols. However, I encourage the use of virtual platforms for such engagements. Restaurants should provide take-away services, and should, as much as possible, avoid seated services."" On February 24, Ghana received 600,000 vaccine doses through COVAX and they are scheduled to roll out to the public on March 2.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307022840/https://presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/news-style-2/1866-it-is-in-our-collective-interest-to-take-covid-19-vaccine-vp-bawumia    https://web.archive.org/web/20210306173631/https://presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/speeches/1865-update-no-24-measures-taken-to-combat-spread-of-coronavirus

A, B, C: AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccine  Ghana was one of the first countries to receive vaccines through COVAX. 600,000 doses were received on February 24 and they started to administer them to the public on March 2. The Health service has published vaccination site information in different districts around the country. A main goal of the COVAX initiative is to provide doses for at least 20% of countries' populations. Ghana aims to vaccinate 20 million Ghanians by the end of 2021. Due to the criteria above, I have coded Ghana as a 2. There is no evidence of cost for recipients; the vaccine was funded by the COVAX initiative.   "So, from Tuesday, 2nd March, to Monday, 15th March 2021, the Ghana Health Service will begin deployment of the six hundred thousand (600,000) AstraZeneca vaccines, with persons in Groups 1 and 2 being the target of this first vaccination campaign. It will be conducted in forty-three (43) districts, which are the epi-centres of the pandemic in the country. They are twenty-five (25) in Greater Accra, sixteen (16) in Ashanti, and two (2) in the Central Region."   "Group 1 is categorised as “persons most at risk and frontline State officials”. It includes healthcare workers, frontline security personnel, persons with underlying medical conditions, persons sixty (60) years and above, and frontline members of the Executive, Legislature and Judiciary.  Group 2 is made up of other essential service providers and the rest of the security agencies."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307022840/https://presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/news-style-2/1866-it-is-in-our-collective-interest-to-take-covid-19-vaccine-vp-bawumia    https://web.archive.org/web/20210306173631/https://presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/speeches/1865-update-no-24-measures-taken-to-combat-spread-of-coronavirus    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307021132/https://ghanahealthservice.org/covid19/downloads/vaccine_administration.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210307020522/https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2021/03/04/971798030/ghana-greets-historic-vaccine-delivery-with-a-dose-of-skepticism

Since January 9, all travellers arriving from countries where new strains of the coronavirus have been identified are required to undergo COVID testing upon arrival. Such travellers may also undergo mandatory quarantine at Gambian government-designated facilities, at the traveller’s own expense. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210209020546/https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Since January 9, all travellers arriving from countries where new strains of the coronavirus have been identified will be required to undergo COVID testing upon arrival and may also undergo mandatory quarantine at Gambian government-designated facilities, at the traveller’s own expense. See: https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ [web archive not working, webpage last updated Feb 16th 2021]

Note: In early February, the government launched the first ever nation-wide study on Knowledge, Activity and Practices (KAP) on COVID-19. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210215214658/https://thepoint.gm/africa/gambia/national-news/vp-touray-gambia-registers-highest-covid-19-in-africa [the web archive link was playing up, so in case of a broken link, the original article is this: https://thepoint.gm/africa/gambia/national-news/vp-touray-gambia-registers-highest-covid-19-in-africa]

COVID-19 testing can be done at the Medical Research Council (MRC) in Fajara, or at several Gambian government-run testing facilities at Independence Stadium, Bakau, KMC; Buffer Zone in Latrikunda, KMC; Brusubi Main Roundabout, adjacent to Petroleum House, WCR; and Brikama, behind Mbalet Junction, WCR. Testing is typically available at the Gambian government-run sites Monday-Friday, and is provided at no cost.  See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210209020546/https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
No vaccine rollout strategy yet and no vaccines have been approved at this point. See https://web.archive.org/web/20210209020546/https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Note: The Gambian government has also no approved any COVID-19 vaccine for use. See https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ [web archive not working, webpage last updated Feb 16th 2021]

Note: Gambia is preparing to receive vaccines from COVAX (most likely Oxford/AZ) and is finalising preparations for the vaccine rollout. The priority is to give the first injections to frontline health workers and other vulnerable groups such as the elderly and those with underlying medical conditions. See http://www.china.org.cn/world/Off_the_Wire/2021-03/02/content_77261256.htm [web archive unavailable]

Upon arrival passengers will be subjected to medical screening and quarantine unless they come from a nation featured in the list of quarantine-exempt country. Schools are still open in Liberia, as they have been since Dec 1, 2020. Archived link is a newsletter from the American International School of Monrovia talking about students back on campus.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210215193736/https://www.aismonrovia.com/newsletters/
Schools remain open.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210224191355/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2FLiberiaMOE

There are COVID-19 safety protocols in place in schools in Liberia. For example, the Ministry of Education in collaboration with its Grant Agent, the UNICEF launched the distribution exercise of Safe School Health Kits for all Private and Public schools in Liberia in January 2021. The initiative intended to equip schools with the necessary protective gear and accessories that are needed to ensure safe school environment as students return to school amid the COVID-19. See https://moe-liberia.org/ministry-of-education-moe-begins-distribution-of-safe-school-health-kits-for-both-all-schools-in-liberia/ [web archive unavailable]

Covid-19 Test Protocol @ RIA    For all non-travelers, sample collection is free.  All in-coming travelers staying more than 5 days have to be tested within 72 hours or three days before departure  Test results can be obtained from www.covidresults.org  All out-going travelers have to be tested within 72 hours or three days before departure  Sample Collection/Testing Center is located at Union Center, Sophie Road, Congo Town, Monrovia.   To obtain your certificate, visit  www.liberiacovidtravel.org  For questions or concerns, email us at unioncenter.lib@gmail.com or call +231776871219  Cost for testing is 75 USD for in-coming and out-going travelers.  Union Center is open for testing @ 8 AM to 4PM every day    https://web.archive.org/web/20210215202939/https://www.nphil.gov.lr/index.php/covid-19-travel-guidance/

Lesotho returned to “Orange Level” restrictions on 3 February 2021. Only essential businesses and services may operate. The list of essential businesses has been expanded to include street vendors and a wider range of retail outlets.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210212141240/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

Lesotho returned to “Orange Level” restrictions on 3 February 2021. Only essential businesses and services may operate. The list of essential businesses has been expanded to include street vendors and a wider range of retail outlets. All retail stores, hardware shops and supermarkets are permitted to operate between 8am-4pm. There are limits on customer numbers and regulations on sanitisation must be followed. Hair salons may operate an appointment-only service. No fitting services in clothes stores.  Liquor stores can operate Monday to Thursday between 10am and 4pm.  All over the counter essential service providers are permitted to operate with 50% maximum staff capacity. Digital payment methods are encouraged. Fuel stations may operate 24 hours.  Textile and manufacturing industries can operate at 50% capacity for both a day and night shift.  Hotels and restaurants may open. Hotels must restrict occupancy to one person per room unless they are spouses. No buffet or communal eating or private service bar is permitted. No conferences or workshops can be held. Restaurants, cafes and fast food outlets can operate a takeaway service. Gyms, parks and sporting facilities are closed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222090556/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

Lesotho returned to “Orange Level” restrictions on 3 February 2021. Only essential businesses and services may operate. Everyone is required to remain at their place of residence except when accessing or providing essential goods and services.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210301091839/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/lesotho/coronavirus

The Lesotho Ministry of Health has confirmed more than 8,900 cases of COVID-19 within its borders. Following a three-week lockdown period which increased the lockdown alert to “Red Level,” the government of Lesotho has decreased the lockdown alert to “Orange Level” effective February 3, 2020. The return to Orange Level maintains restrictions on many activities including mandatory masks in public places, a nationwide curfew each day from 9:00 pm to 5:00 am, and limits gatherings of any kind to a specified number of attendees.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210207223802/https://ls.usembassy.gov/lesothos-new-directive-on-coronavirus-international-arrivals-now-asked-to-self-isolate-for-14-days/
