Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? Entry into Lesotho currently prohibited for all travelers. On January 12, 2021, Prime Minister Moeketsi Majoro announced the closure Lesotho’s land borders and suspended all flights into the country, with limited exceptions. Such exceptions include the transportation of fuel, cargo, and goods or emergency medical attention.  Negative COVID-19 Test Required: Any travelers to Lesotho will need to present a negative COVID-19 test not older than 72 hours from the time of departure. In Lesotho and Mexico, PIH made community engagement a central pillar in our COVID-19 response. Both teams focused on training and equipping community health workers with up-to-date information on the virus, personal protective equipment, and contact tracing tools. This community health approach—closely coordinated with local government systems—played a crucial part in connecting people to care effectively and reducing the toll of the disease on their lives.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301095534/https://www.pih.org/article/local-health-systems-key-responding-global-covid-19-pandemic-and-beyond

There have been no further updates to international travel controls. International flights to Nosy Be are allowed but other airports remain closed to international passengers.  However, travel from countries experiencing high numbers of COVID cases, is currently suspended.  All international flights to Madagascar are currently suspended, including private flights as of 16 January. Tourist flights to/from the island of Nosy Be restarted on 1 October, but onward travel to the mainland of Madagascar is not permitted. Travellers from countries on the risk list, cannot enter the country via this route.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210222191448/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222192334/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/madagascar/coronavirus

No further updates have been published: The IMF has noted a number of measures as of February 4th, 2021.    Key measures include: (i) targeted investments to strengthen the health system following the activation of the national contingency plan in coordination with the WHO to protect against the pandemic; (ii) expansion of social assistance to the most vulnerable, including cash-transfers and in-kind necessities to the poorest and those unemployed; and (iii) supporting private sector through tax relief, suspension of government fees and waived social contributions. As of end of July, medicine and medical equipment were exempted from paying import duties.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210222190820/https://twitter.com/SE_Rajoelina  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222204233/https://twitter.com/PresidenceMada  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222204322/https://twitter.com/diplomatieMg  http://archive.today/2021.02.22-204214/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19%23M

Testing capacity seems to be limited. Symptomatic individuals should attend their nearest health centre. PCR, antigen and serology tests are available, and results are often distributed within 72 hours. Polyclinique Ilafy and Hospital ManarapenitraAndenatepenaka offer PCR tests for COVID-19. InstitutPasteur offers serological tests for COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210222205029/https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus/country/madagascar?country=~MDG  http://archive.today/2021.02.15-122722/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/  http://archive.today/2021.02.15-123652/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/madagascar/coronavirus

It's believed that Madagascar has contact tracing systems in place from previous experiences dealing with Ebola and Plague. Additionally, screening and tracing was used to identify specific positive cases and their residence previously.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210222205532/https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/fancybox/3.2.5/jquery.fancybox.min.css

Air and land borders are open. Enhanced screening and quarantine measures are in place. Incoming travellers must present a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before travel. Those unable to present a negative test result on arrival will be tested and then quarantined until results are returned.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/444171/mali-domestic-covid-19-restrictions-remain-mostly-unchanged-as-of-feb-17-update-9

Air and land borders are open. Air travellers are required to wear a mask. Enhanced screening and quarantine measures are in place. Incoming travellers must present a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before travel. Those unable to present a negative test result on arrival will be tested and then quarantined until results are returned. https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/444171/mali-domestic-covid-19-restrictions-remain-mostly-unchanged-as-of-feb-17-update-9  https://web.archive.org/save/https://ml.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"Any passenger who arrives without a negative COVID-19 test result or with a COVID-19 test result dated more than seven days before arrival will have their travel documents retained by airport officials and will be subjected to testing. Travellers must self-quarantine at home or at a hotel at their expense until the test result is available. Anyone suspected of having COVID-19, despite presenting a negative COVID-19 test result, will be subject to testing."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308234507/https://ml.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Mali's government says it has chosen to use the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine in its plan to initially immunise 4.2 million people by the start of April. Health minister Fanta Siby said that the vaccination would first target medical staff, the elderly and those with comorbidities.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.africanews.com/2021/01/22/mali-picks-astrazeneca-covid-19-vaccine-to-begin-vaccination-april/

Starting Thursday, October 1, 2020, access to Mauritius for all long-stay arrivals may be approved with a traveler-financed mandatory 14-day quarantine at an establishment recognized by the authorities, which includes multiple COVID-19 PCR tests. Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Mauritius? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  COVID-19 tests are available at the C-Lab laboratory at Wellkin Hospital on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 09:00 to 12:00. Patients must dial 605-1000 to book an appointment.  Results are available within 48 hours.  Cost of Rs.2500 (approximately $60 USD) must be paid in full by the patient. Visit Wellkin Hospital’s COVID-19 announcement (French) for additional information - https://archive.vn/2oGf9#selection-1829.0-1849.36

No change. However, the Government of Malawi has issued on 4th February an extension of school closures "by another two weeks starting from 8th February, 2021".    See Malawi's Ministry of Education's Facebook post (contributor's note: the Government does not release most of its press releases on its own website), archived:  https://archive.vn/gG3cH

On 4 February, the Government of Malawi issued a press statement announcing "that school closure[s] will be extended by another two weeks, starting from 8th February, 2021". "All students in boarding secondary schools as well as residential students in colleges and universities should be released to go back home for these two weeks."    See Malawi's Ministry of Education's Facebook post (contributor's note: the Government does not release most of its press releases on its own website), archived:  https://archive.vn/gG3cH

No change in policy.    As per the US Embassy in Lilongwe on 28th Jan, "Beginning Monday, January 18, ... a curfew is in place from 9pm to 5am and all markets must close at 5pm and all drinking establishments must close at 8pm. Hotels and lodges are operating but with strict COVID-19 measures."    See US Embassy's COVID-19 Information page, archived at https://archive.vn/t2IZs

No change in policy. "All activities that involve an audience, such as music shows, sports, arts, and religious gatherings, are restricted to 50 people or fewer."    See US Embassy in Malawi's COVID-19 Information page, archived at https://archive.vn/t2IZs

No change in policy. The US Embassy in Lilongwe notes on 22nd January that "the government has implemented other measures to limit the spread of the virus, including... no gathering of more than 50 people"    See the US Embassy's update on their website, archived at https://archive.vn/8WiDq  See also, the previous data point's archive (President's speech on 17th Jan), at https://web.archive.org/web/20210125105334/https://theworldnews.net/mw-news/chakwera-address-jan-17-covid-19-demands-change-of-priorities-and-scaling-down-of-campaign-promises

No policy changes. Latest communication on public transport was on 26 Jan, when the Ministry of Transport and Public Works issued a press release reiterating that "the gazetted Public Health (Corona Virus and Covid-19) (Prevention, Containment and Management) Rules 2020 are still in force", and that "all public service vehicles (Buses, Minibuses and Taxis) should reduce their seating capacity to 60% whilst observing social distance", and that "no standing passengers [are] allowed on any public service vehicle".    See Malawi Government's twitter post, archived at https://archive.vn/aaYnW, see aforementioned post's press release picture, archived at https://archive.vn/aCbfV
No policy change found.
No policy change found.

There is no change in policy. As per the US Embassy in Lilongwe on 22nd January, "the government of Malawi requires all arriving passengers to produce a negative SARS Cov-2 PCR test certificate obtained within 10 days prior to arrival and to complete a health declaration form.", and US citizens are permitted to enter (see Embassy's COVID-19 Information Page, archived at https://archive.vn/t2IZs)    There is no quarantine for arriving passengers. Per the 22nd Jan health alert update by the US Embassy in Lilongwe, "the government requests all arriving passengers to self-monitor for 14 days, after which district health officials will follow up with them". Random testing is in place in addition to the prevailing entry restrictions of furnishing a negative PCR test certificate - "Arriving passengers may be required to provide samples for Covid-19 testing. Samples will be collected at the airport and test results will be communicated to the concerned within 48 hours."    Additionally, "all land borders remain closed except for essential goods transporters, deportees, and those in special circumstances," and "foreigners may not travel to Malawi via land borders".    See archive at https://archive.vn/8WiDq (US Embassy Health Alert Update, 22 Jan), and https://archive.vn/t2IZs (US Embassy COVID-19 Information page, last updated 28 Jan)

No new policies found. There are no updates to IMF's own fiscal and economic policy tracker (last updated 7th Jan for Malawi), notes no updates to the policies that have lapsed at the end of last year.    See IMF's own website, archived at https://archive.vn/usdt8#M
No data to indicate either way

No change. The Government of Malawi continues its coordinated public information campaign.     On social media: The Government of Malawi continues to provide daily information on the number of new cases and deaths on The Ministry of Health's Facebook page (see for example, https://archive.vn/X7hLa (11th Feb) and https://archive.vn/c1gZe (12th Feb)), Twitter page (see for example, https://archive.vn/3s4Cg (11th Feb) and https://archive.vn/fe4Of (12th Feb)), and provides an information dashboard online (https://covid19.health.gov.mw/) and on WhatsApp (both platforms are noted in the graphics released from the government, available from the archived weblinks in this note).    On traditional media: Additionally, on 10 Feb, Ministry of Civic Education and National Unity Timothy Mtambo "updated the [country] in a speech on strategies and progress undertaken by his ministry [in the dissemination of information relating to Covid-19]", where he notes that "apart from radio stations and television, his ministry has engaged Ministry of Information to employ loud hailing, through public address system, as a strategy to reach out to those who have no access to radio and television".    see Malawi Government's Twitter tweets, archived http://web.archive.org/web/20210210164612/https://twitter.com/MalawiGovt/status/1359544069010120704

No policy change. On 29 January, Co-chairperson of the Presidential Taskforce on Covid-19 Dr John Phuka in his daily case updates wrote and reiterated that "the pathway for COVID-19 testing for anyone experiencing the symptoms and for all contacts of the confirmed cases is through the District Health Offices/District Hospitals. All contacts of the confirmed cases will be tested whether symptomatic or not.", and that such testing "for those with symptoms, suspected cases and contacts, the services are free of charge."    See the Ministry of Health's Facebook post, archived at https://archive.vn/DYfKm

On 11 February, the Ministry of Education referred a press release from the Ministry of Health, where it is announced that there is an increase in sites conducting antigen Covid-19 tests around the country to 206. Most of such facilities are available to the public for free.    See Malawi Ministry of Education's Facebook post, archived at https://archive.vn/QvXlM
No mention in any further degradation/improvement in contract tracing since from the last data entry update.

No policy change since last input; additionally, the US Embassy in Lilongwe notes that Malawi has a "mandatory face mask usage [policy]," and "those who do not comply with the mask mandate may be subject to fines."    See US Embassy in Malawi's update on their website, archived at https://archive.vn/8WiDq

No change; there is still no availability on the vaccine in Malawi.    On 4th February, Co-Chairperson of the Presidential Taskforce on Covid-19 Dr John Phuka indicated in his daily situation update that Malawi "will roll out COVID-19 vaccination next month and the vaccine to be used is [the Oxford-AstraZeneca] vaccine", and reiterated that "it will target 20% of the population which include the frontline health workers and other social workers, the elderly and those with comorbidities"; and that "[such] preparations are at [the] advanced stage".  See Ministry of Health's Facebook post, archived at https://archive.vn/nX2PA    On 7th February, President Lazarus Chakwera announced during his Presidential Address on Covid that the country will receive 1.5 million doses of the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine during its first consignment, expected to arrive at the end of February.  See the BBC's summary, archived at https://archive.vn/Tu5iy

Travelers arriving with a negative result that is older than 7 days will be placed in quarantine and tested for COVID-19 on the same day at their own cost and will only be released if the results of this test return negative.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210215202043/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Arriving international tourists do not have to quarantine if they present a negative COVID-19 PCR test result that is not older than 7 days.  However, non-Namibian travelers (except US) arriving with a negative result that is older than 7 days will be placed in quarantine and tested for COVID-19 on the same day at their own cost.  If the results of this test come out negative, they will be released from quarantine.  If positive, they will be isolated at their own cost, according to Namibia’s isolation protocols.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210221215811/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No vaccinations yet. The government has paid to acquire enough vaccine doses to vaccine 20% of the population through the COVAX Facility.  Namibia may receive a small–scale “first wave” of vaccine deliveries as early as the end of January or February.  Additional resources need to be secured for acquisition of additional doses to vaccinate at least up to 60% of the population in order to achieve a desirable level of herd immunity.  Namibia will prioritize frontline health care workers and population groups vulnerable to severe COVID-19 once the vaccine becomes available.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210221215811/https://na.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Country-Specific Information    The Nigerien Ministry of Public Health has confirmed 4,612 cases of COVID-19 in Niger, including 165 deaths.  Niger is currently under a national health state of emergency due to the COVID-19.  Restaurants, markets, and stores are open.  Bars, night clubs, and performance venues have been ordered closed since December 24.  Large gatherings for weddings, funerals, and baptisms are banned.  It is mandatory to wear a face mask or other objects that cover the mouth and nose in Niamey in public places, markets, and urban transport.  People must respect a distance of at least one meter between people in open spaces, restaurants, businesses, airports, and other public places. Entry to Niger  Entry to Niger is only permitted for Nigerien nationals, persons with valid residency and foreign nationals with valid visas.    Testing on arrival  From 1 August 2020 if you are eligible for entry, you will need to present a negative COVID test certificate less than 72 hours old to the airport authorities, or be tested at the airport.    You should not use the NHS testing service to get a test in order to facilitate your travel to another country. You should arrange to take a private test.    You will be subject to temperature checks upon arrival.    If you test positive for COVID you will have to isolate in government facilities for 14 days after arrival.    Quarantine requirements  If you arrive in Niger by air with a negative COVID-19 test, you will have to self-isolate at your final destination (home, hotel) for seven days. Government of Niger health teams will visit regularly to ensure compliance. The Nigerien police will retain your passport during the seven-day self-isolation period. On the seventh day of self-isolation you will need to take a second COVID-19 test; if the result is negative you can end self-isolation and if the result is positive you will have to follow government isolation procedures.    If you test positive for COVID-19 upon arrival in Niger you will have to isolate in government facilities for 14 days after arrival. All those quarantined are tested for a second time on the 13th day of quarantine.      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210201183818/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/niger/entry-requirements

FISCAL  An updated crisis response plan has been presented to donors with an estimated cost of 18.4 percent of GDP, divided into an immediate health response and broader economic and social mitigation. Key elements are already being implemented, such as food distribution, two months of free utilities to the vulnerable households and temporary tax relief for hard-hit sectors. Finance Ministry also announced credit support to the private sector in the form of loan guarantees. The revised cost includes large-scale support for agricultural production, revenue shortfalls, and the building of liquidity buffers. On May 8, the cabinet approved a supplementary budget with 1.3 percent of GDP in resources re-allocated to additional spending toward health, security and social assistance.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210208152328/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

COVID-19 Testing    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Niger? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  COVID-19 PCR tests are conducted at the Center for Medical Research and Health (CERMES) located here.  The test costs 30,000 FCFA and a certificate of test results are ready for pick-up from the same location within 24 to 48 hours of testing.  Appointments can be made by phone between 8 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. at the following numbers: 2075 2040, 2075 2045, 8852 6448, or 8009 0111.  to make an appointment.  Once a certificate of the test result is issued, it will be valid for 72 hours.  The test costs 30,000 FCFA and a certificate of test results are ready for pick-up from the same location within 24 to 48 hours of testing.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210208145337/https://ne.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Country-Specific Information    The Nigerien Ministry of Public Health has confirmed 4,612 cases of COVID-19 in Niger, including 165 deaths.  Niger is currently under a national health state of emergency due to the COVID-19.  Restaurants, markets, and stores are open.  Bars, night clubs, and performance venues have been ordered closed since December 24.  Large gatherings for weddings, funerals, and baptisms are banned.  It is mandatory to wear a face mask or other objects that cover the mouth and nose in Niamey in public places, markets, and urban transport.  People must respect a distance of at least one meter between people in open spaces, restaurants, businesses, airports, and other public places.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210208145337/https://ne.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

All bars will remain closed. https://web.archive.org/web/20210216060523/https:/rw.usembassy.gov/health%E2%80%AFalert%E2%80%AF-u-s-embassy%E2%80%AFkigali-rwanda-february-3-2021/

A mandatory nightly curfew between 9pm and 5am (local time, GMT) came into effect for the regions of Dakar and Thiès on 6 January. During curfew hours, everyone must stay at home or indoors, except for essential government service workers. The motorways between the international airport and Thiès and between the airport and Mbour are closed between 8pm and 6am.  The Government of Senegal has advised that the airport will remain open and existing flight schedules will not change. People can still travel to the airport during curfew if they are passengers arriving and departing or the driver (no other people accompanying passengers are allowed). All of these people must carry a copy of their passport and plane ticket, which will allow for movement to the airport or to their accommodation. If you are arriving into Senegal at the airport in curfew hours, you should contact the person or taxi company you have arranged to collect you in advance to make sure they can still access the airport and have all the necessary paperwork.  There is currently no restriction on travel between regions, and authorisation is not needed to travel between regions. Internal flights have also restarted. Masks must be worn at all times in public areas and when travelling, including in a private car if there are two or more people in the car.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/senegal/coronavirus

The Government of Senegal has implemented restrictions that impact entry into Senegal for certain foreign nationals. Travelers who are not citizens or residents of Senegal or a country that is a member of the Economic Community of West African States, or who do not meet certain other exemptions outlined here, may be denied entry or face difficulty traveling to Senegal.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210224195621/https://sn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Travellers who are not citizens or residents of Senegal or a country that is a member of the Economic Community of West African States, or who do not meet certain other exemptions outlined here, may be denied entry or face difficulty traveling to Senegal. https://web.archive.org/web/20210227221356/https://sn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

•  All travelers to Senegal over the age of two years must present an original COVID-19 test certificate showing a negative result. The test must occur within five days of entry into Senegal. The results must be from a PCR test (not a rapid test) and be issued by a laboratory approved for such testing or a recognized international health organization.  Travelers transiting Senegal must also show such proof if they will be present in Senegal more than 24 hours or wish to exit the airport.   •  Verification of testing compliance will be undertaken by the airline prior to departure.  Passengers without a negative COVID-19 test may not be permitted to board.   •  All travellers to Senegal may also be required to complete a passenger location form for public health officials, in accordance with recommendations from the International Civil Aviation Organization.  The form will be collected on arrival. The form is available for preview and download here.   •  The Government of Senegal has implemented restrictions that impact entry into Senegal for certain foreign nationals.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://sn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

From 3rd March all local flights and interstate movements of people were suspended.    Source: On 3rd march large public gatherings were banned for 30 days.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308153906/https://allafrica.com/stories/202103040185.html

A negative COVID-19 test is required to exit Somalia, taken no more than 72 hours before travel.  Screening is under the guidance of UN and World Health Organization representatives in Mogadishu.  Egal International Airport (Hargeisa) has put in place additional measures to screen passengers arriving at Hargeisa by air, including temperature checks.  All passengers must wear a face mask.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210222101734/https://so.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

All incoming passengers must have a negative COVID-19 test conducted within 96 hours before travel.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210228124222/https://so.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No information to suggest a change in policy.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308161324/https://so.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Somalia on Monday [1st March] made the face masks mandatory after rise in COVID-19 cases amid a deadlier second wave.  Omar Mohamud Mohamed Filish, mayor of Mogadishu, the largest and most populated city in the country, announced the use of face masks in all public places mandatory amid the rising numbers of coronavirus cases and deaths.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308152335/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/somalia-deadlier-2nd-wave-makes-face-masks-mandatory/2160893

The US Embassy in South Sudan states that The Med-Blue Laboratory in Juba is the only authorized private testing facility in South Sudan. The Med-Blue facility is located in the TECNO building in Juba.  Testing is available 7 days a week, 8:00 a.m.-6:00 p.m.  The facility accepts walk-ins, or you can call +211 92 388808 to request an appointment.  Cost for the test is between $115-$150. Airports reopened on January 14, 2020. Land borders continue to be restricted for authorized missions. According to the UK government travel advisory, “All passengers from the UK are banned from entering Chad until further notice due to the new COVID-19 variant. All international travellers need to present a negative COVID-19 PCR test certificate dated no more than 72 hours prior to arrival in Chad.” Travelers staying in Chad for more than 7 days need to quarantine in a home or hotel, respect prevention measures, and are required to take a COVID test on the seventh day. Coding 3 due to the ban for travellers from the UK.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301020941/https://www.humanitarianresponse.info/sites/www.humanitarianresponse.info/files/documents/files/sitrep_covid-19_n340_26_fevrier_-_2021.pdf    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210228222503/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/chad/entry-requirements    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210228222405/https://td.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/       - https://web.archive.org/web/20210301023652/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Entry rules in response to coronavirus (COVID-19)  Entry to Chad  Airports have re-opened for commercial flights. All passengers from the UK are banned from entering Chad until further notice due to the new COVID-19 variant.All international travellers need to present a negative COVID-19 PCR test certificate dated no more than 72 hours prior to arrival in Chad.    If you enter Chad and are planning to stay for 7 days or more, you will need to surrender your passport, quarantine at home for 7 days and take a COVID-19 test on the seventh day. Passports will be returned upon presentation of the COVID-19 test receipt. If you’re staying in Chad for less than 7 days you will not be need to quarantine.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308184644/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/chad/entry-requirements

There are programs in place for business and people, from tax exemptions, deferred payments, suspension of payments for hard hit house holds as well as a food distribution program.    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210214194719/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No change in policy. The IMF continues to report that “Measures were also taken to alleviate the hardship on households, including (i) temporary suspension of payments of electricity and water bills for the lifeline consumption, as well as (ii) Replenishment of the national food distribution program (Office National de Sécurité Alimentaire, ONASA) (0.5 percent of non-oil GDP).”    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210301023652/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

FISCAL  Financing for COVID-19 health-related expenditures are estimated at CFAF 42 billion (0.8 percent of non-oil GDP), which are being implemented under a national contingency plan. Key measures include: (i) training of medical and technical staff, (ii) purchase of necessary medical equipment, (iii) construction of seven health centers in remote areas, (iv) construction of three mobile hospitals, and (v) securely managing entry points. Additionally, the capacity of Farcha Hospital in N'Djamena is going to be expanded and the hiring of additional health workers is in process. The authorities have also decided on a package of fiscal measures to help businesses weather the shock: (i) for SMEs, the authorities will, among other things, reduce by 50 percent the business license fees and the presumptive tax for 2020, (ii) tax breaks such as carryforward losses and delays in tax payments will also be examined on a case-by-case basis, (iii) clearance of domestic arears of about CFAF 110 billion owed to suppliers, (iv) a subsidy planned to the agricultural sector (0.3 percent of non-oil GDP), and (v) the simplification of the import process for food and necessity items, including health equipment, and tax exemptions for these items. Measures were also taken to alleviate the hardship on households, including (i) temporary suspension of payments of electricity and water bills for the lifeline consumption, as well as (ii) Replenishment of the national food distribution program (Office National de Sécurité Alimentaire, ONASA) (0.5 percent of non-oil GDP), (iii) the National Assembly adopted a new law on May 11 that establishes a Youth Entrepreneurship Fund (0.6 percent of non-oil GDP), (iv) payment of all death benefits due to deceased civil and military agents, indemnities and ancillary wages owed to retirees and payment of medical expenses for civilian agents and defense and security forces (0.1 percent of non-oil GDP), and (v) the national assembly adopted the law on September 26 that establishes the solidarity fund for the vulnerable population amounting to CFAF 100 billion. The 2020 supplementary budget, which includes the COVID-19 measures, was enacted by the Parliament in August.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308152023/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Government is actively asking to respect prevention measures & social distancing along with compulsory mask wearing.  -  https://web.archive.org/web/20210214194213/https://td.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  -  https://web.archive.org/web/20210214194118/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/chad/coronavirus  -  https://web.archive.org/web/20210214194719/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The government continues to enforce social distancing and mask measures. “Wearing of face masks when outdoors is compulsory throughout the country with penalties, including potential imprisonment, for non-compliance.”     The Chadian Ministry of Public Health (Ministère de la Santé Publique du Tchad) publishes communiqués with COVID-19 infection statistics on their website and with more regularity on their official Facebook page. "The National Health Response Coordination invites the population to remain calm, united, vigilant and reminds the strict compliance of barrier measures, in particular physical distancing.”    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210301011233/https://sante-tchad.org/communique-de-presse/    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210301011556/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/chad/coronavirus

Policy still in place.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308185602/https://td.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210301011556/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/chad/coronavirus
Tests are available at hospitals and typically provide results the next day.  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210214194213/https://td.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The government notes that travellers arriving in Chad must quarantine for 7 days and get tested on the seventh day. It also has a policy in place to "Test all people departing from N’Djamena to the provinces for education or similar activities." It also reports having laboratories set up in different cities throughout the country and the latest data from each one. The UK travel advisory site and the US Embassy continue to report that PCR tests are available in Chadian hospitals with results readily available within 72 hours.    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210301020941/https:/www.humanitarianresponse.info/sites/www.humanitarianresponse.info/files/documents/files/sitrep_covid-19_n340_26_fevrier_-_2021.pdf    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210301011556/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/chad/coronavirus    -https://web.archive.org/web/20210228222405/https://td.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

COVID-19 Testing    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Chad? Yes.   If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes.   COVID tests can be obtained in one of the Chadian hospitals entitled to carry out the PCR test. The PCR test costs 15,000 FCFA (approximately USD $30).   The test result is typically printed and the hard copy is usually available the next day.   For information on limited humanitarian exemptions, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308185602/https://td.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

I see initial investments in medical staff and health centers but nothing specifically calls out contact tracing.  I do not see any sites or official information from Chad's government.    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210214194719/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The Chadian government reported to the WHO that “As of February 26, 847 contacts associated with the confirmed cases, of which 846 have been followed.” A 19 February OCHA quick alert notes that “In the provinces, most cases are contact cases whereas in N’Djamena they are travelers” alluding to contact tracing. An existing library of daily situation reports prepared by the Chadian government for the WHO and OCHA report consistent contact tracing since March 2020.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301020941/https://www.humanitarianresponse.info/sites/www.humanitarianresponse.info/files/documents/files/sitrep_covid-19_n340_26_fevrier_-_2021.pdf    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210301023332/https://reliefweb.int/report/chad/chad-quick-alerts-19-february-2021     Library of Daily OCHA/WHO Situation Reports:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301022341/https://www.humanitarianresponse.info/en/operations/chad/documents/themes/covid-19

COVID-19 Testing    Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Chad? Yes.   If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes.   COVID tests can be obtained in one of the Chadian hospitals entitled to carry out the PCR test. The PCR test costs 15,000 FCFA (approximately USD $30).   The test result is typically printed and the hard copy is usually available the next day.   For information on limited humanitarian exemptions, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308185602/https://td.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry? No  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? Yes  All travelers whether foreigners or returning residents whose countries or airlines require them to provide negative testing for COVID-19 as a condition for traveling will be required to present a certificate on arrival. Travelers from other countries with symptoms and signs related to COVID-19 infection will undergo enhanced screening and may be tested on arrival.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210215192716/https://tz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Government of Tanzania is implementing temperature scanning for all international passengers arriving into Tanzania. If you show symptoms of COVID-19 on arrival, you may be required to take a test. The Tanzanian government has not released aggregate numbers on COVID-19 cases or deaths since April 2020. Public information campaigns are limited and also some methods like "steam therapy" are lacking in scientific temperament.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210215194613/https://www.bloomberg.com/tosv2.html?vid=&uuid=757b3a70-6fc6-11eb-8e49-31244fb695cc&url=L25ld3MvYXJ0aWNsZXMvMjAyMS0wMi0xMi9jb3ZpZC0xOS1jcmlzaXMtZ3Jvd3MtaW4tdGFuemFuaWEtYXMtcHJlc2lkZW50LXJlamVjdHMtcmlza3M=  http://web.archive.org/web/20210215192716/https://tz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Tanzanian government somewhat acknowledges the presence of COVID-19, but the prime minister does not really seem to take it seriously given the lacking restrictions and interventions.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210222191241/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-55900680

While there are no coordinated campaigns, public officials have been involved in encouraging some efforts such as wearing of masks.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210308181332/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-56145510
Eligibility requirements are difficult to locate, but testing overall appears limited:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210206234106/https://tz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Testing is available through Government of Tanzania laboratories.    The details of testing (including test type and performance characteristics) have not been made available nor independently verified.  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? The Tanzanian Ministry of Health, Community Development, Gender, Elderly, and Children (MoHCDEC) states that individuals will receive their test results within 72 hours.  However, results are not always returned within a timely manner and there are reports of individuals receiving inconclusive results and being asked to repeat the test after several days.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210215192716/https://tz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Meetings and gatherings of up to 200 people are allowed (including political rallies) but participants must maintain a social distance of 2 metres in all directions at all times and masks must be worn. Shopping malls, arcades, supermarkets, pharmacies, hairdressers and salons are open. From 14 November, cinemas, casinos, gaming centres and gyms are allowed to open as long as appropriate social distancing measures are in place. COVID-19 standard operating procedures (SOPs) are in place for arriving and departing passengers. On arrival at Entebbe International Airport and at land border crossings, travellers will need to provide a negative COVID-19 test certificate issued no more than 120 hours before boarding the aircraft. Airlines have been directed not to allow passengers without a negative test certificate to travel. Foreign national passengers who arrive without a valid negative test certificate will be denied entry. Infants aged three and under are exempt as long as the accompanying parents have a negative test certificate.  Arriving passengers will be subject to temperature checks and will be screened for infectious diseases by the Port Health authorities. If a passengers shows signs or symptoms of any infectious disease they will taken by ambulance to a local isolation centre to undergo a COVID-19 test at their own cost. Test results will be returned within 24 to 48 hours; passengers will be expected to remain at the isolation centre until the test results are returned.  If a foreign national tests positive for COVID-19 and wishes to be repatriated for treatment outside of Uganda, they will be expected to cover the costs themselves.  Departing passengers are required to present a negative COVID-19 PCR test certificate, issued no more than 120 hours before travel. The 120 hours begins on the day the sample is collected for testing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208195406/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/uganda/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208195447/https://ug.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-page/
No real changes in policy noted.  https://archive.vn/6775V

/web/20210303155938/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/uganda/entry-requirements  On arrival at Entebbe International Airport and at land border crossings, travellers will need to provide a negative COVID-19 test certificate issued no more than 120 hours before boarding the aircraft. Airlines have been directed not to allow passengers without a negative test certificate to travel. Foreign national passengers who arrive without a valid negative test certificate will be denied entry. Infants aged three and under are exempt as long as the accompanying parents have a negative test certificate.    With effect from 19 December 2020, passengers arriving or departing from Entebbe International Airport can only be picked up or dropped off by a maximum of two people, including the driver, in order to avoid crowding. Vehicles with more than the authorised number of people will not be allowed access to the airport.  Arriving passengers will be subject to temperature checks and will be screened for infectious diseases by the Port Health authorities. If a passengers shows signs or symptoms of any infectious disease they will taken by ambulance to a local isolation centre to undergo a COVID-19 test at their own cost. Test results will be returned within 24 to 48 hours; passengers will be expected to remain at the isolation centre until the test results are returned.

A laboratory test carried out on medical prescription can identify the SARS-CoV-2 virus infection.  However, this test is of no use in the absence of symptoms. Your personal physician is in the best position to assess the value of the test in your case. If needed, contact your physician via telephone. The Ministry of Health's Testing Eligibility Tool recommends isolating and monitoring for those with general symptoms, while those with severe symptoms must get in contact with the Ministry of Health to arrange for a test and receive medical attention.    Travelers are expected to cover all costs associated with their COVID-19 test.  Average cost for testing is UGX 350,000. Delivery of test results may be via email, text message (i.e. a PDF send via WhatsApp) or physical copy.  Make sure to confirm a delivery method that suits your needs before selecting a company/lab to conduct the test.  It is recommended  to bring a printed copy of your test results with you to the airport; an electronic copy may not be accepted. A COVID RDT Antigen test can be done next to the airport in Entebbe at the Kazuri Medical clinic (+256 0702 199 000 / +256 0787 199 788, Plot 168 Kampala Road, Katabi, Entebbe). The antigen test takes 15 minutes and costs 50 USD, certified results are provided onsite.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208211534/https://www.health.go.ug/covid/faq/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208211617/https://www.health.go.ug/covid/project/testing-eligibility-tool/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208195447/https://ug.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-page/

A number of health facilities in Kampala offer COVID-19 testing. For a full list of accredited laboratories and approved sample collection points, please visit the Ministry of Health’s website.  Travelers are expected to cover all costs associated with their COVID-19 test https://archive.vn/6775V#selection-1939.0-1943.80

Before 2-15  On January 11, 2021, President Ramaphosa announced the closure of 20 land border crossings, including Beitbridge, Lebombo, Maseru Bridge, Oshoek, Ficksburg and Kopfontein, through February 15, 2021, with limited exceptions. Such exceptions include the transportation of fuel, cargo and goods; emergency medical attention for a life-threatening condition; the return of South African nationals, permanent residents or persons with other valid visas; diplomats; the departure of foreign nationals; and daily commuters from neighboring countries who attend school in South Africa  https://web.archive.org/web/20210215190458/https://za.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/    Effective 2-15-20221 20 land borders will reopen on Monday, says Motsoaledi. As of December 1, the Government of Zimbabwe requires all new arrivals to the country to present a negative COVID-19 test result issued within the previous 48 hours.
